text: i'm henry fountain science writer for
The New York Times this is one of the
boiling water reactors that's been
damaged in Japan like all nuclear power
reactors it uses uranium fuel to
generate heat this is the heart of the
reactor where the uranium fuel is
arranged in long thin rods at all times
water is kept circulating around the
rods to keep them cool when the tsunami
came it destroyed the pumping systems
that kept water flowing through the rods
the cooling stopped and the water around
the rods started boiling away the heart
of the reactor is surrounded by a
concrete and steel shell called a
containment structure this serves to
keep radiation from entering the
environment when the fuel rods were
exposed the exposed fuel rods generated
hydrogen which collected outside the
containment structure this eventually
exploded blowing the top off the reactor
building another major concern are the
used fuel rods that were taken from the
reactor and are stored in pools
elsewhere in the building outside the
containment structure without pumps to
keep water circulating in the pools the
water will eventually boil away and more
radiation will be released American
officials say that this has already
happened at one of the pools and that
large amounts of radiation are being
released this is an example of problems
that just one of the reactors but the
power station has six and problems have
been reported at at least four of them
this has made it very difficult to stay
on top of the situation
